data: SMART TRACKING OF AIR POLLUTION BY A BIKE LIGHT

Currently, cities perform air quality monitoring by static and sparse stations that to large cities cost about € 4 Mill. These systems do not offer robust, tempo-spatial heterogeneous measures to take efficient decisions. In order to overcome these drawbacks, we have developed TRACKER, a sensor device adapted for bikes that provides a cost effective way for cities to deploy mobile sensor networks. TRACKER combines sensor technology with Low Power Wide Area (LPWA) communications technology, providing an autonomous sensor platform which can be integrated into Bike Sharing Schemes. Also, it has movement sensor and theft alert.
See.Sense is a successful company founded in 2013 to develop bike devices that collect data to improve resource usage and infrastructure for citizens. We have commercialised 2 cycling products which has allowed us to double our revenue each year and received multitude of awards. Cities as Dublin, Belfast, Milton Keynes (leader in smart cities) have trusted in us.
We aim at disrupting into the Smart Cities Market-estimated to grow from € 281 Bill (2015) to € 683 Bill (2020). Our target market, Bike sharing systems, is settled in more than 1,000 cities in 50 countries. TRACKER is a patent pending technology for what we have invested € 0.5 Mill to take to TRL 6. We plan to start our sales in Dublin and Boston where we are performing tests. 
Yet, we still need to test network coverage, and get our technology validated by the end-users as well as develop a plan dissemination and exploitation activities.
Thus, we have decided to continue with TRACKER for what we need an additional investment of € 3 Mill, that will give us a ROI of 7.0 by 2024. Thus, we consider essential to perform a detailed feasibility study to continue with our project and decided to ask for funding through this SME instrument.
Achieving a European transport system that is resource-efficient, environmentally friendly, safe and seamless (08.02.03.04)

YOUNG ENTREPRENEURS SHINE (Y.E.S)

Our strategic partnership is made up of five primary schools, located in island regions within the European Union; , Kefalonia (Greece), Las Palma (Spain), Sicily (Italy), Wolin (Poland) and Northern Ireland (UK). 

Together, we have identified two areas of common concern: 

(1)The economic crisis facing the European Union is having a massive negative impact on our regions, which are overdependent on tourism & public services, & facing rising unemployment & a lowering of living standards .

This economic crisis provides the motivation for our schools to begin a process to embed Entrepreneurship Education into our curricula. We recognise that our pupils require a new skill set as they enter an ever-evolving, ever-demanding global job market; but more than that, they need the transversal skills that will enable them to act as entrepreneurs, who will provide the innovative spark to create new jobs & bring new wealth to their communities.

To achieve this goal, we recognise the need to 'upskill' our teachers in the delivery of  a more open-ended, activity-based, experiential approach to learning, to enable our children to develop these skills. Consequently, our project will include collaboration between our schools to enable our teachers to learn from each other, both virtually, via eTwinning/Skype etc., and face-to-face, at transnational Learning, Teaching & Training events.

In addition, our staff will collaborate, within & between our schools, to develop a new, skills-based scheme of work for Entrepreneurship Education, with clear learning outcomes for our pupils. We want to embed Entrepreneurship Education  into our school curricula from the early years, so that entrepreneurship will become part of the unique ethos of our schools.

Through collaboration in a series of open-ended, entrepreneurial challenges, our pupils will develop the entrepreneurial attitudes of self-confidence, determination, resilience, & self-awareness, alongside the entrepreneurial skills which enable them to think in new & imaginative ways, to generate, implement, test and review innovative solutions to a variety of problems or business opportunities. Our senior pupils will have opportunity to enter competitions, to form mini-companies & engage in meaningful collaborations in real situations, undertaking real roles & producing real products and services.

The apex of our pupil collaboration will take place during short term pupil exchanges, where they will form international teams to create products for sale or demonstration at an International Trade Fair in the host school or community.

The immediate impacts of our project will be evidenced in the professional development of our staff & their increased motivation & confidence; the embedding of an entrepreneurial ethos & Entrepreneurship Education in our schools and; in pupils, who are problem-solvers, confident, innovative, adaptable & creative, who engage with, and value, their learning, & who are more employable & ready to take responsibility for their own futures & that of their local communities.

We will become beacon schools for Entrepreneurship Education, & will ensure that the results of our partnership will be made available beyond our partnership, in local schools & the wider international learning community, through a series of teacher meets, workshops, job shadowing opportunities and publishing our results on eTwinning, Erasmus +, Open Discovery Space, Euro and our website(s) etc.

We will also challenge our Educational Authorities to make Entrepreneurship Education a statutory component of our primary school curricula & to provide schools with curriculum materials, schemes and resources & a national scheme for accreditation similar to other awards e.g., International School Award, Fair Trade School etc.

(2) Our secondary objective concerns the migrant crisis sweeping Europe, creating increased tensions in communities and stresses within our schools.

We see the destructive potential of migration without social integration & inclusion. We understand the dangers of xenophobia, misinformation, fear, racial violence, discrimination, radicalization, ghettoization etc. To that end we want to create harmonious schools, where newcomer  children, their families & their cultural expressions are welcomed, respected & celebrated within an inclusive school community. We plan to implement the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, through pursuit of the Rights Respecting School Award.

Consequently, our staff and pupils will collaborate to agree, explain, & implement a set of positive values by which our school communities will live.

The impact will be in more harmonious schools & communities, where pupils respect each others' rights, whilst understanding their individual & collective responsibilities. We will seek to widen the impact of our work by disseminating our experiences to local schools & the international learning community.
Ku wyjątkowej i innowacyjnej edukacji. Europejskie doświadczenia źródłem naszego sukcesu.

Objectives of the project:
- improving the level of teaching and updating the methods of teaching
- providing  provision for our more able pupils
- developing teachers`skills connected with the use of ICT during classes and outdoor
- acquiring specific tools and strategies to promote a positive climate in school and prevent students`conflicts and cyberbullying 
- improving language skills
- increasing teachers`competences in working  with special needs students

There are 10 teachers involved in this project: two  English teachers (4-8 grades), 1  English young learners  teacher  1 German teacher, 1 history teacher, 2 maths teachers, 1 biology teacher, 1 PE teacher and 1 pedagogist. 

During the realization of the project there will be 21 foregin mobilities- 5 courses and 2 job shadowings in three schools. Substantive,methodological and psycholocical courses are connected with:  conflict management in classroom , dealing with bullying and cyberbullying, deleloping critical thinking with board games,  using ICT and multimedia in teaching and English fluency  development. 
Job shadowing aims at obserwing effective ways of English teaching, maintaining disciplnie in class and using ICT in classroom. Furthermore, teachers would like to find new ways of working with special needs children, promoting healthy lifestyle and ecology and implementing CLIL method. 

All those actions will bring lots of benefits both to the participants and to our school thanks to taking those actions into concideration and into account when creating school plans and school programmes, thanks to sharing knowledge and experiences with other teachers as well as using the methods and solutions acquired during the courses and job shadowing. The actions will have impact especially on:
- improvement and modernization of the process of teaching and upbringing. This will improve students`educational achivements and discipline
- development of more able pupils
- increasing the level of using the ICT in teaching
- improving skills in dealing with classromm conflicts and bullying
- learning more about the culture of different cultures. This will increase the openess and tolerance of our pupils towards different cultures

Thanks to the dissemination the influence of the project will be bigger. Not only the teachers of our school and local area but also those from other countries can take advantage of our experiences and our help during the realization of their projects.
'Playing to Learn' - Developing Early Years Education and Learning

'Playing to Learn'; Developing Early Years Education and Learning

Our school is embarking on an exciting and challenging phase in its development, as we establish a new nursery. We want to develop a nursery with children's play at its heart. A vibrant nursery, bubbling over with daily adventures, imagination, creativity, curiosity, ingenuity, exploration, challenge and fun. A secure home, away from home, where children 'Play to Learn'. 

We believe that children learn best through open-ended play, and place great value on their acquisition of the so called, 'soft skills' of collaboration, concentrating, resilience, using one's own initiative, questioning, testing, risk taking, taking responsibility for one's own actions, empathy etc. These 'soft skills' are the foundations, upon which, all future learning will be built.

However, as a new provider, we are aware of our relative inexperience and the need to develop our professional skills and competences as early years practitioners. We need to learn when and how to intervene and interact with the children to enrich their learning experiences.  We also need to develop and enhance our skills and competences in the organisation, management and day-to-day running of our nursery unit.

To that end, we have applied for an Erasmus+ KA1 grant to enable us to achieve our objectives for our pupils' learning, for our staff's professional development and the effective operation of our nursery unit. Our partners in Greece and Estonia are applying simultaneously for a similar KA1 grant. 

We propose to send six members of staff, chosen from our Senior Management and Early Years' Teams to International Conferences in Iceland and Spain, around the theme of Play-based Learning. It is hoped that the training and knowledge our staff receive will inspire and empower them to take forward this innovative play-based approach to the curriculum.

They will further investigate a play-based, experiential approach to learning, by travelling to pre-schools in Greece and Estonia, to observe best practice; to shadow colleagues; to team teach with them; to learn together in workshops around pre-agreed themes; and to enter into a professional dialogue with their staff. 

We believe that, our participation in this international learning community will help us develop as early years practitioners and will provide a creative force in our pre-school, transforming and enriching our children's learning experiences, empowering them, developing their self-esteem and promoting positive attitudes as they ‘Play to Learn’. 

In addition, we believe that our more experienced partners from Greece and Estonia, will benefit from reciprocal visits to Northern Ireland, and that together we will enhance the International profile of our schools.  It is our shared hope that we can become flagships for good practice in our local regions and further afield. 

We commend this project to you and know with complete certainty that it will make a real difference in the lives of our pupils and staff and in the development of our school.

ΔΗΜΙΟΥΡΓΟΥΜΕ ΔΕΣΜΟΥΣ-ΕΠΙΚΟΙΝΩΝΟΥΜΕ ΜΕ ΟΛΟΥΣ
Η ΤΕΧΝΗ ΕΝΩΝΕΙ ΤΟΥΣ ΛΑΟΥΣ ΤΗΣ ΕΥΡΩΠΗΣ

The necessity of early interventions as far as children's mental health and social development is concerned  and the teachers' professional upgrade caused the design of this Project. We need to αdopt innovative programmes in a frame of European cooperation. We have already realized the previous project in Erasmus KA1 with training courses in Europe and now we want to go on with one step further. So we choose to design a project in ERASMUS KA1-Job Shadowing with two mobilities for two teachers of our school respectively.

TARGETS OF THE PROJECT

-children'phisical, social and mental health
-Developing new curriculum plans to ensure each class in our school via comparison the educational programmes in Europe.
-Reinforcing the International outlook of our school by introducing innovative educational tools into our classes.
-development of the teachers' ability in communication in order to ensure their mental health and manage difficult situations in the class.
- teachers' profecional development and feedback
 -compensatory action in order to manage the inequalities in education.

Two teachers of our school who will realize this project, have a lot of activities and studies in Drama in Education and enviromental education, so they are able to integrate the aims of the project, improving and enforcing their knowledge and abilities with interactive methods in European schools.

PROGRESS OF OUR PROJECT

1. PREPARATION
The educational stuff of our school prepare plans, submite ideas and activities in order to have satisfactory results. They have permanent communication with colleagues in Europe for an efficient cooperation.

2. DESIGN A WEEKLY EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMME 
The teachers of our school organize two programmes that they will realized when we'll host our partners of Europe.
Programme 1-The development of children' mental health and emotional empathy via Arts (music-drama in education-paintings). It will be based on playing that is the most important tool in pre-school education.
Programme 2- Environmental programme with outdoor activities and stimulies from Arts. Painting activities with recycling materials and materials from nature.

3.INTERCHANGE VISITS WITH PARTNERS IN EUROPE SEPTEMBER-OCTOBER-DECEMBER 2017
Teachers of the partnership will interchange visits in order to observe teaching familiar items with different educational tools  depending on other teachers' interests and studies . The items that will be elaborated are: mental health, environmental education and fialanagnosia. One of our teachers will go to Ireland and the other one to Spain.  Three teachers from Ireland will be hosted in our school and two from Spain.

4. EVALUATION
The evaluation will be realized throughout the program so as for possible shortcomings to be pointed out and improving changes to be planned by means of questionnaires, interviews and videos. Evaluation will be realized at the end of the program too, for drawing conclusions and future reflection.


5. EXPIRY-DIFFUSSION 
   a. The educators of our nursery school with the school advisor's co-operation will organize an educational meeting where all the nursery school teachers of our city will be presented with the good practices of this project. Consequently the new effective educational tools will be widely spread to colleagues from other schools. 
   b. The organization of open activities in outdoors spaces for pupils of other nursery schools and their teachers with experiential methods like drama in education and a lot of stimulies of Arts would give the chance in other schools of our city to realized the necessity  of these programms that aim  to children' and teachers' mental health and good communication .This activity would create all the preconditions for feature co-operation. 


Application this project it would be expected to be planed a creative learning environment for our pupils,  teachers and parents. Furthermore we lay down the bases for new European cooperations in future and ensure the sustainability of our project.
Safety and Protection of built Infrastructure to Resist Integral Threats

Terrorist attacks by bombing or CBR-agents are threats with a low probability but with disastrous consequences. There is strong need to protect people, the societal community and critical infrastructures and utilities against being damaged, destroyed or disrupted by deliberate acts of terrorism. Solutions have to be derived to realize sufficient resilience of the urban infrastructure for rare occasions with minimum effect on normality. Hitherto, normal regulations and building guidelines do not take into account the CBRE threat. Fortunately, the required specialist knowledge is available on explosion dynamics, response of structures, dispersions of toxic agents and the injuries. This knowledge should be explored to derive the required solutions. Therefore, the SPIRIT Consortium was formed to bring the required expertise together, make these commonly available and to find solutions that can be integrated into normal life and planning and building procedures. Within SPIRIT a terrorist attack with the whole scope of CBRE-threat is addressed. The main outcome of the project is an integrated approach to counter CBRE-threats, including proposed guidelines for a EU Regulatory Framework. With this approach, government, end users of buildings and designers can define and achieve a desired level of protection. The SPIRIT contribution to built infrastructure protection will be: - A methodology to quantify the vulnerability of built infra in damage, number of injuries and loss of functionality and services; - A guidance tool to assess the vulnerability and define efficient and effective countermeasures to achieve a required protection level; - Draft guidelines to enable safety based engineering and the incorporation of CBRE protection; - A suite of ready to use CBRE countermeasure products. The overall goal of the SPIRIT project is to contribute to people safety and increase the resilience of built infrastructure against a terrorist attack.
Improving the crashworthiness of composite transportation structures

The European aerospace, automotive, and rail industries are committed to improving their energy efficiency to meet targets set within the EU’s climate, energy and transport policies. This is motivating the increased use of lightweight composite materials in lieu of heavier metallics. To implement this transition, these industries must reach, at least, the same level of crash performance achieved with metals, but at significantly lower weight and without increasing cost. This is viewed by industry as an exceptionally challenging goal and will require highly trained engineers, versed in the myriad aspects of designing cost-effective, crashworthy composites structures, and capable of harnessing the latest research developments in the fast-changing world of composites. The ICONIC ETN aims to cultivate such a new generation of young engineers; comfortable and fluent in the integration and exploitation of knowledge from fields as diverse as materials science, chemistry, computational methods, solid and damage mechanics, textile technology, structural design and optimisation. These researchers will acquire the skills to enable the sustainable and economically-viable design of a new generation of highly efficient, lightweight transportation composite structures that will provide the maximum protection to occupants through superior crashworthiness. 15 Early Stage Researchers (ESRs) will be recruited to take up posts, across the UK, Ireland, Greece, Germany, Italy and Sweden, in an innovative, multidisciplinary and intersectoral structured research and training programme.  ICONIC is supported by a strong consortium from academia, large industrial enterprises and innovative SMEs. A comprehensive training and secondment programme (including joint supervision and industrial mentoring) will equip researchers with additional transferable skills to ensure future employability and career progression.

SEE3 will offer invaluable 2-week industry traineeships to learners and apprentices; 12 Construction, 10 IT, 14 Sport, 10 Performing Arts, 10 Early Years, 12 Travel and Tourism, 10 Animal Management, 10 Catering, 20 Food Service plus 3-month traineeships to 2 Catering apprentices with experienced receiving partners in Portugal, Malta and Spain. The project builds on SERC Mobility and SEE2 in Sport, IT, Early Years, Performing Arts, Construction, Catering, Animal Management and Travel & Tourism. 

New partner Education&Mobility, Fuerteventura will source and secure traineeships in Sport and Food Service using established local placement providers. FFUSL will offer direct traineeships in digital marketing for tourism and secure traineeships in IT with local digital companies; Trainee+Up will provide Animal Management traineeships with Barcelona Polo club and secure Performing Arts traineeships with local theatre companies;  FEGREPPA will offer traineeships at local bakeries and patisseries and provide a combination of in-college training and work placement for 2 long-term placements. New partner Bragamob, Portugal will secure traineeships at local construction companies and day care nurseries. Established partner Luxol will deliver Sport traineeships using their own coaching staff. The Special Educational Needs student plus one other from her college cohort will travel with the Sport group from SEE2.

Project objectives are based on the learners' needs and the College's strategic plans for European development and internationalisation which complement the partners' aims and purposes:
1. Develop & consolidate an increased number of strong and effective European partnerships with relevant organisations to develop learning & teaching practices. This will build the capacity of SERC's internationalisation policy and underpin the development of European/International curricula .
2. Widen learner participation in European mobility opportunities:
•Further develop vocational & technical skills;
•Increase exposure to diverse cultural experiences;
•Improve language competences;
•Further develop personal & social competences including team work, communication, problem solving & confidence;
•Enhance employability;
3. Widen staff participation in European mobility opportunities for professional development - upskilling staff in technical areas & education & industry developments to expand their teaching capabilities; gaining knowledge from learning & teaching pedagogies; & developing personal competences associated with collaborative projects such as organisation & communication skills. A key focus of SERC's Staff Development Policy.

Key results expected for the learners include a meaningful industry experience with increased technical knowledge & professional skills in their chosen sector, working with professionals, applying & improving upon course knowledge, learning new techniques & methods.
Construction: practical application of learned methodologies & project work
IT: develop skills in using IT for communications
Sport: develop skills in coaching children
Performing Arts: backstage skills
Early Years: teaching activities & reflecting on their own practice
Travel and Tourism: learn digital marketing skills for the industry
Animal Management: caring for thoroughbreds at a professional stable
Catering: learn traditional baking techniques
Food Service: develop skills & knowledge relevant to the delivery of food & beverage services 

Further to the skills relating to their qualifications & industry, the project aims to develop other personal, social & employability skills valued by employers that a traineeship, and particularly a work experience abroad, offers such as self-management, teamwork, leadership, communication, problem solving, decision making & organisation skills. It will provide the learners with a better understanding of the workplace skills needed & how to learn from the placement to set career-related goals.

'SEE 3' will also impact on the professional development of staff through upskilling in all partner organisations. Each flow of 10 or more learners will be accompanied by 2 staff members per week. As well as personal skills & enhanced cultural awareness, the staff will be able to access industry information which will help to update their knowledge in an EU context; & improve technical ability which will all contribute to curriculum development in terms of content, delivery and introducing an EU dimension.
In the longer term the project will allow the College to develop its capacity to deliver a quality curriculum and European opportunities for staff & students. It will contribute to the College's main objectives as set out in the College Development Plan - "To improve the quality and relevance of education and training by providing a curriculum that will inspire, transform and enrich", and "To tackle the skills barriers to employment and employability".

'SEE 2' proposes to offer invaluable 2 week industry traineeships to 24 Construction, 10 IT, 10 Sport, 10 Performing Arts, 10 Early Years, 20 Travel and Tourism, 20 Animal Management and 20 Catering learners and apprentices with experienced receiving partners in Italy, Malta and Spain over a 2 year period. The project builds on SERC's previous mobility programmes in Construction and Sport, and current projects in Sport, IT, Early Years, Performing Arts, Construction and Catering. The receiving partner in Malta, Luxol, will deliver the Sports traineeships using their own coaching staff and will secure traineeships in IT and Construction using  established local placement providers. The receiving partner in Italy, Uniser, will source and secure traineeships with local theatres and children's nurseries using their extensive network of placement providers. One of the receiving partners in Spain, FFUSL, will offer direct traineeships in digital marketing for tourism; another, Trainee+Up will source traineeships in the local zoo or animal shelters; and the final Spanish receiving partner, FEGREPPA, will offer training and traineeships at local bakeries and patisseries.

The project objectives are based on the learners' needs and the College's strategic plans for European development and internationalisation which complement the partners' aims and purposes:
1. Develop and consolidate an increased number of strong and effective European partnerships with relevant organisations in order to develop learning and teaching practices. This will build the capacity of SERC's internationisation policy and underpin the development of a European/International curricula in time
2. Widen learner participation in European mobility opportunities with a view to:
•Further develop vocational and technical skills
•Increase exposure to diverse cultural experiences
•Improve language competences
•Further develop personal and social competences including team work, communication, problem solving, and confidence
•Enhance employability
3. Widen staff participation in European mobility opportunities for professional development purposes - upskilling staff in technical areas, and education and industry developments to expand their teaching capabilities; gaining knowledge from learning and teaching pedagogies; and developing personal competences associated with collaborative projects such as organisational and communication skills. This is a key focus of SERC's Staff Development Policy.

The key results expected for the learners include a meaningful industry experience with increased technical knowledge and professional skills in their chosen sector - working with professionals applying and improving upon what they have learned on their course and learning new techniques and methods. For Construction this will be practical application of learned methodologies and project work, IT learners will develop skills in using IT for communications, Sports learners will develop skills in coaching children, for Performing Arts this will be in backstage skills, for Early Years it will be in carrying out activities and reflecting on their own practice, and specific practice in Reggio Emilia and Montesorri, Travel and Tourism will learn digital marketing skills for the industry, Animal Management will develop skills in exotic animal care, and Catering learn traditional baking techniques. Further to the skills relating to their qualifications and industry, the project aims to develop other personal, social and employability skills valued by employers that a traineeship, and particularly a work experience abroad, offers such as self-management, teamwork, leadership, communication, problem solving, decision making and organisational skills. It will provide the learners with a better understanding of the workplace skills needed and how to learn from the placement to set career-related goals.

'SEE 2' will also impact on the professional development of staff through the upskilling of staff in all partners. Each flow of 10 or more learners will be accompanied by 2 staff members per week. As well as personal skills and enhanced cultural awareness, the staff will be able to access industry information which will help to update their knowledge in an EU context; and improve technical ability which will all contribute to curriculum development in terms of content, delivery and introducing an EU dimension.

In the longer term the project will allow the College to develop its capacity to deliver a quality curriculum and European opportunities for staff and students. It will contribute to the College's main objectives as set out in the College Development Plan - "To improve the quality and relevance of education and training by providing a curriculum that will inspire, transform and enrich", and "To tackle the skills barriers to employment and employability".
Ambassadeurs voor Europa door Erasmus+ : beter onderwijs  voor iedereen door kennisuitwisseling in Europa

"Every student internationally  competent "  is  Friesland College's slogan in the upcoming policy plan in 2018. Presently we focus on increasing  the number of students and professionals going abroad and on receiving more students from our 
European partners, not only for VET but also for Adult Education. Our strategic partnerships strenghten the bond with our partners abroad. Curriculum comparison and exchange of good practice enriches our educational programmes.  Students share their experiences with peers and on social media and their enthousiasm make them the best Ambassadors for Europe. We want our students to get acquainted with European values and to get used to working with people from different cultures.  Internationally compent students also means focus on Internationalisation at Home. Workshops, cross-sectoral projects and choice modules International 1 and 2 are already part of the curriculum.

The quality of our placements abroad remains one of our goals. Therefore we use solid and renowned training companies recognised by SBB. This is safeguarded by agreements with companies in the context of the new Qualification files of the Dutch government. In the Learning Agreements of Friesland College (i-BPV) content, monitoring, validation, recognition and evaluation of the experiences abroad is described. 

The realisation of ErasmusPro placements for apprentices is a new challenge.  Some of the education programmes will investigate the possibilities for students with an employee contract to go abroad for a special training for at least 3 months.  That requires consultation with employers.  For that reason, we will apply for some Advanced Planned Visits.(APV) 

We will give attention to the European Year of Cultural Heritage 2018  for those countries that  joined this initiative.  An assignment will be incorporated in the choice module International 2 (Working abroad) as well as an elaborate preparation for their period abroad.  
Modern Language choice modules,  in view of the professional context, can be considered as a new element in the Erasmus+ grant allocation. 
 
Developing SOCIAL ENTREPRENEURSHIP, the new approach of empowering students of level  4+ EQF.   Communication skills, using English in a natural setting, meeting young people in other countries, being part of their peer-to-peer training in social entrepreneurship are themes within this programme. Developing personal leadership in a programme of excellence enables them to follow a path of growth, on a multisectoral level. Teachers and students will be trained abroad within the companies involved.  This training enables students to start up companies while studying.  The collaboration with Higher Education students will be extented. They will  be involved for guidance of our students and for research matters.

We continue our social inclusion project for our 2EQFstudents of Facility Management and Care taking,  the socially challenged group of students who we offer a placement of 3 weeks  on Malta for their personal growth and for improving their position on the labour market. This group will be accompanied by 2 professionals. An elaborate selection procedure and extensive preparation is part of the allocation proces. 

Internationally competent students demand international competent teachers. Personal and professional development  is becoming increasingly important in relation to Excellence and quality control and in view of their role as Ambassador.  The professionals are well aware of the importance of their input and influence on the educational programmes.
Improving the educational proces and stimulating new innovative approaches in education  within Europe through curriculum comparison,  exchanging of good practice, jobshadowing,  workshops are part of the assignments for our staff. They will also be involved in describing Learning Units and Learning Outcomes for ECVET matters.  The difference in educational systems in Europe remains a challenge.

Leeuwarden and Valletta (Malta) are the Capitals of Culture 2018.  Sharing our experiences of the effect on the cultural diversity, economic situation of the regions involved and labour markets is one of the goals we want to achieve.   A large number of students and teachers support the projects of Cultural Capitals.  The number of  outgoing and incoming students from countries involved increase enormously.  Friesland College has  full heartedly committed to joining  the festivities and supporting the activities and international cooperation. In this call attention will be paid to sharing our experiences with  students and professionals in Plovdiv (Bulgaria) and Matera (Italy), the capitals of culture in 2019.
Developing Work Based Learning Model for VET. Partnership between VET and Business

The VET mission is to support learners in acquiring knowledge, skills and competences to successfully enter the world of work. Therefore work experience is a fundamental aspect of vocational training across Europe. 



The Skills4Work project aims to improve work experience pathways for VET students by creating and validating a Work Based Learning implementation model engaging VET organisations and business. The emphasis is on learning from each other’s experience and engaging in a real dialogue with employers by developing the model in close collaboration with local enterprises. Through practical implementation of different work based learning approaches and feedback from enterprises, the project will develop hands-on implementation guidelines that will improve significantly the quality of work experience for both the VET students and enterprises in partner countries. The project will benefit VET teachers by creating CPD materials and transnational transfer of good practice through joint peer learning events organised as part of the CPD.  



Project objectives are:

• To learn about existing work experience programmes in partner countries through practical study visits organised for VET teachers as part of the CPD strategy. To foster mutual learning between project partners. 

• To set up a VET & Employers Working Groups in each partner country to collaborate together on developing and validating WBL implementation model and engaging in a dialogue on meaningful work experience practices. 

• To develop WBL implementation guidelines for VET.

• To develop CPD materials for VET teachers. 

• To extend employer participation in work-based learning practices across partner countries.

• To disseminate project outcomes across EU Member States.



The focus of this project is on the practical exercises in Ireland, Slovenia, Germany and the UK that will evaluate effectiveness of different WBL models and engage in collaboration local enterprises. Based on that the following two outcomes will be developed aimed at VET providers, teachers and students as well as employers across EU:  

1. WBL implementation model for VET

2. CPD materials for VET teachers

3. VET - Business Partnership



The target groups of the project are:

• VET organisations

• VET providers

• VET teachers

• VET students

• Enterprises

• Policy Makers

• Research Bodies and Experts



The project Consortium is composed of 6 organisations from 4 European countries bringing a wide range of knowledge and experience in the field of work based learning, pedagogy, technology and vocational training:



1. H2 Learning Ltd. from Ireland, an expert in providing services to education sector in the use of ICT technologies and innovative CPD strategies. 

2. City of Dublin Education and Training Board (CDETB), the biggest VET provider in Ireland with 3,000 staff and 40,000 learners.

3. The Slovenian Institute for Vocational Education and Training (CPI), a leading institution in Slovenia to develop methodologies. and prepare modern education programmes for pre-secondary and secondary vocational education and college expert education. 

4. The Solski Centre Vocational School from Slovenia that cooperates with more than 300 local companies and is very active in work based learning practices, providing work experience for 300 VET students every year.

5. The OSZ IMT Vocational School from Germany, the largest IT College in Berlin cooperating with 600 IT companies in the region. 

6. South Eastern Regional College from the UK, one of the largest Further Education Colleges in Northern Ireland actively collaborating with local communities and managing 3,000 apprentice/training places across the country. 



Creating opportunities for quality work-based learning is one of the main challenges of European education and training policies. 

A lack of workplace experience and related skills and competences is one of the factors contributing to the ‘skills gap’ in the EU today, where many young people faces unemployment and in the same time employers struggle to recruit skilled workforce. The project will address this challenge by supporting VET teachers in preparing and assisting their students in taking a first step into the world of work.

Technology offers significant opportunities for VET providers but also presents challenges, as by its very nature it changes at a fast pace. In order to maximise the potential technology can have on learning and teaching, the VET workforce must be supported to develop the skills and competences to enhance digital integration into their classroom practices. TELMS aims to address the need for appropriate use of TEL within education provision and the facility to support the staff to embed this in the classroom. The project consortium will jointly develop a programme which will facilitate the partners to establish an ILT peer mentoring programme which allow the partners to explore how TEL can be embedded across the curriculum using a peer mentoring strategy whilst promoting the professional development of staff in ICT methodologies.The partnership comprises of H2 Learning from Ireland, an e-learning expert as well as 4 VET organisations: VET College from CDETB in Ireland, SERC, a VET College in the UK; the Solski centre, a VET School in Slovenia; and Malignani, a VET technical institute in Italy; bringing a range of technological & pedagogical skills and knowledge.  All of the partners have varied experience in digital integration, professional development of staff and mentoring, and although SERC has witnessed the benefits of TEL strategically implemented through a peer mentoring approach its development was carried out in isolation. The project is innovative to the partners as it goes beyond the mere functionality of the technology, offering deeper pedagogical support and upskilling so that staff can fully realise the instructional potential of the technology to benefit learning and teaching. TELMS is a 2 year project and the objectives are:1. To develop a Teacher Peer Mentoring Programme in the effective use of ILT & associated learning and teaching strategies,2. To develop a Teacher Toolkit,3. To develop TELMS Online Platform,4. To train 8 mentors at a transnational short-term staff training event in Northern Ireland,5. To support the 8 mentors to establish & deliver an ILT Pedagogy Mentoring Programme to 16 teachers in the partner institutions,6. To disseminate project outcomes across EU Member States. The target groups of the project are:• VET organisations and providers• VET teachers• VET learners• Policy Makers, Research Bodies and Experts.The project will jointly realise the following products aimed at VET teachers and providers across the EU:1. Train the Teacher Programme - to build teacher capacity and ensure that they can mentor their peers in the utilisation of a range of appropriate technologies and associated digital learning strategies2. TELMS Teacher Toolkit to support the training and provide valuable resources and guidance on implementation in the classroom3. TELMS online platform to facilitate access to innovative training resources for TEL. Teachers will be encouraged to explore the resources and discuss their experiences of using the technologies and the effective implementation of the pedagogical strategies suggested through an on-line community forum.Participation in the TELMS project offers an opportunity for the partners to upskill teachers and develop the organisation's capacity by facilitating learning experiences for the staff which will ultimately impact on the learners; and providing access to new materials to support the teachers' professional development through the implementation of a pedagogy mentoring programme. In the long term, through the embedding of the programme into the institutions provision and professional development practices, the programme will become a permanent and evolving tool for upskilling VET teachers.

Due to the economical deprivation in Northern Ireland and in the Derry area we strongly feel that the Derry and North West area will benefit from the opportunity of developing further competences, linguistic capabilities and cultural awareness in a global context.  We will work with the North West Regional College, SERC and our European partners to implement the #ETC project which will incorporate ECVET principles to provide a transparency to participants.  This will also allow the learning outcomes and assessments to be recognised and validated within the partnership network and in our local partner networks.
The Northern Ireland Tourist Board has devised a strategy to increase the number of visitors to Northern Ireland.  We feel that the #ETC project will help make recent graduates more employable by providing them with the opportunity to live and work abroad and then bring the skills, innovation and creative ideas they have developed during their training back to Northern Ireland and Derry to improve on the services and products offered to visitors.  
The value in our project comes from the strong network that already exists between Foyle and our partners.  We have all worked in projects, many of us in ECVET projects and are committed to providing quality training mobilities.  
Due to the success of a previous project managed by Foyle the successful employment rate of past participants is 73%.  Particularly in the tourism area and one of our most successful local companies (GoD group) which owns numerous hotels, bars and restaurants, has stated their commitment to offering participants possible employment as they see the cultural and professional benefits of these European mobilities to their businesses.
We plan to send 60 learners/recent graduates connected with the tourism and hospitality fields to carry out a detailed programme which will allow them to develop professional and technical knowledge, skills and techniques.  They will also work towards achieving learning outcomes as agreed with the NWRC and SERC colleges. 
The objectives of our project are:
* To encourage lifelong learning and continuous professional development & for participants to see the benefits of continued training, especially in another European city 
* To help participants progress in their chosen career fields - ultimately helping to make a participant more employable
*  To provide suitable training and to support participants in acquiring new or developing existing knowledge, skills & competences in the field of tourism or hospitality & tourism
*  To bring Europe closer to participants and show the opportunities that exist
*  To develop an awareness, respect and an appreciation for multi-culturalism
*  To promote the learning of a second European language 
*  To develop and strengthen co-operation with our project partners and ensure that all involved are committed to providing quality training, ensuring that participants have a positive experience
* To develop new partnerships and networks- not just for Foyle and its partners but also for the participants and host companies
*  To implement ECVET principles and courses designed for a key action 2 project (VET towards ECVET)as an integral part of the training process and to provide a level of quality assurance using ECVET tools such as MoU, Learning Agreements, Competence Appraisal and Certification to ensure all parties are in agreement and will work towards meeting the projects objectives.   
*  To develop a competence appraisal which will recognise and validate achievement and improved ability obtained during the training period
*  To develop a competence appraisal that will recognise and validate the acquiring and development of skills
*  To award certification and recognition for the meeting of agreed Learning Outcomes.
*  To promote the confidence and levels of self-esteem for participants for future job searches
Ultimately, the main objective  of our #ETC project is for participants to successfully find employment in the local labour market or the European Market.

'SEE' proposes to offer invaluable industry traineeship programmes of 2 weeks duration to 20 Performing Arts, 20 Early Years, 20  IT, 24 Sport learners and 1 Gas apprentice with experienced receiving partners in Italy and Malta and an enterprise in the Republic of Ireland over a 2 year period. The project builds on SERC's previous mobility programme in construction and current programme in sport. The receiving partner in Italy, Uniser, will source and secure traineeships with local theatres and children's nursersies using their extensive network of placement providers. The receiving partner in Luxol will deliver the Sports traineeships using their own coaching staff and will secure traineeships in IT using  established local placement providers. The Gas apprentice will complete their traineeship with an enterprise specialising in gas equipment.The total budget requested for 85 learners and 17 accompanying staff is €212,620.00The project objectives are based on the learners' needs and the College's strategic plans for European development and internationalisation which complement the partners' aims and purposes:1. Develop and consolidate an increased number of strong and effective European partnerships with relevant organisations and enterprises in order to develop learning and teaching practices.  This will build the capacity of SERC's internationisation policy and underpin the development of a European/International curricula in time;2. Widen learner participation in European mobility opportunities with a view to:•Further develop vocational and technical skills•Increase exposure to diverse cultural experiences•Improve language competences•Further develop personal and social competences including team work, communication, problem solving, and confidence•Enhance employability3. Widen staff participation in European mobility opportunities for professional development purposes - upskilling staff in technical areas, and education and industry developments to expand their teaching capabilities; gaining knowledge from learning and teaching pedagogies; and developing personal competences associated with collaborative projects such as organisational and communication skills.  This is a key focus of SERC's Staff Development Policy.The key results expected for the learners include a meaningful industry experience with increased technical knowledge and professional skills in their chosen sector - working with professionals applying and improving upon what they have learned on their course and learning new techniques and methods. For Performing Arts this will be in backstage skills, for Early Years it will be in carrying out activities and reflecting on their own practice, IT learners will develop skills in using IT for communications and applying software and hardware, sport learners will develop skills in coaching and team sports, and in gas the apprentice will develop knowledge in gas appliances and regulations. Further to the skills relating to their qualifications and industry, the project aims to develop other personal, social and employability skills valued by employers that a traineeship, and particularly a work experience abroad, offers such as self-management, teamwork, leadership, communication, problem solving, decision making and organisational skills. It will provide the learners with a better understanding of the workplace skills needed and how to learn from the placement to set career-related goals.'SEE' will also impact on the professional development of staff through the upskilling of staff in all partners. Each flow of 10 or more learners will be accompanied by 2 staff members per week. As well as personal skills and enhanced cultural awareness, the staff will be able to access industry information which will help to update their knowledge in an EU context; and improve technical ability which will all contribute to curriculum development in terms of content, delivery and introducing an EU dimension.In the longer term the project will allow the College to develop its capacity to deliver a quality curriculum and European opportunities for staff and students. It will contribute to the College's main objectives as set out in the College Development Plan - "To improve the quality and relevance of education and training by providing a curriculum that will inspire, transform and enrich", and "To tackle the skills barriers to employment and employability".

'SERC Mobility' offered invaluable two-industry traineeship programmes of two weeks’ duration to 20 level 2/3 catering and 24 level 3 construction learners with experienced partners in Spain and Malta over a two-year period. The project builds on SERC's previous mobility programmes in construction and sport. The catering learners completed one week’s vocational training in specialist bakery, patisserie and confectionery with partner FEGREPPA and then accompany their learners on their pre-existing traineeships with local pastry and bakery businesses. The construction learners completed their traineeship within two departments of the Maltese Ministry for Transport and Infrastructure, working in project teams on large scale development projects.

The project objectives are based on the learners' needs and the College's strategic plans for European development and internationalisation which complement the partners' aims:
1. Develop and consolidate an increased number of strong and effective European partnerships with relevant organisations and enterprises in order to develop learning and teaching practices and lead to the development of a more effective and European/International curriculum.
2. Widen learner participation in European mobility opportunities with a view to further develop vocational and technical skills, increase exposure to diverse cultural experiences, improve language competences, further develop personal and social competences, and enhance employability.
3. Widen staff participation in European mobility opportunities for professional development purposes - upskilling staff in technical areas, and education and industry developments to expand their teaching capabilities; gaining knowledge from learning and teaching pedagogies; and developing personal competences associated with collaborative projects such as organisational and communication skills.

The key results for the learners include a meaningful industry experience with increased technical knowledge and professional skills in their chosen sector - working with professionals, applying and improving upon what they have learned on their course and learning new techniques and methods. For catering this was particularly in technical patisserie and bakery, and in construction this was in surveying and drawing practices and processes. Further to the skills relating to their qualifications and industry, the project aimed to develop other personal, social and employability skills valued by employers that a traineeship, and particularly a work experience abroad, offers such as self-management, teamwork, leadership, communication, problem solving, decision making and organisational skills. It provided the learners with a better understanding of the workplace skills needed and how to learn from the placement to set career-related goals.

'SERC Mobility' will also impact on the professional development of staff through the upskilling of staff in all partners. Each flow of 10 or more learners were accompanied by two staff members per week. Staff members identified training needs which were supported through the project. As well as personal skills and enhanced cultural awareness, the staff were able to access industry information which helped to update their knowledge in an EU context; and improved technical ability such as advanced patisserie and confectionery skills. This all contributed to curriculum development in terms of content, delivery and introducing an EU dimension.

In the longer term the project will allow the College to develop its capacity to deliver a quality curriculum and European opportunities for staff and students. It will contribute to the College's main objectives as set out in the College Development Plan - "To improve the quality and relevance of education and training by providing a curriculum that will inspire, transform and enrich", and "To tackle the skills barriers to employment and employability."
El JC1 pone rumbo a tu futuro

«JC1 sets course for your future» is a mobility project that aims to continue with the internationalization of our teachings, improving their quality and providing our VET students with favorable conditions in order to be competitive in the search for employment, while enriching their CV with culture, languages and values of European citizenship.

Given that the JC1 has a trajectory of participation in European programs and projects, our center has as a hallmark the high level of teamwork among its teachers, as well as great interest in following the trajectory of the students after they finish their training, collaborating with them in the search for employment.

The development of this project has a two-fold direction. On one hand, it launches a series of actions directed to teaching staff, so that through the realization of job shadows (three mobilities at homologous centers in Ireland and France), they can learn the strategies and methodologies of other educational systems and incorporate them into the teaching practice in the JC1. The other aspect is that of carrying out 10 students' mobilities in two modalities: short stays (FCT) and ErasmusPro, which will allow them to carry out work placements to improve their professional skills in companies of the respective fields in Italy, Holland and Portugal.

Therefore, the project will allow the educational community of our center to:

- Increase the quality of Vocational Training Education by comparing educational systems in different countries and applying new techniques that improve professional profiles, fostering the optimal development of professional skills.

- Develop the professional, personal and social skills of students in the international arena. Undoubtedly teamwork and coordination with European partners will be key to achieving the objectives, enhancing professional profiles and giving them meaning.

- Offer opportunities to eliminate social inequalities for socially disadvantaged students who, thanks to the project, can reorient their future to find the necessary support for it.

- Enhance the personal and social growth of the participants through cultural and linguistic immersion in other European societies, while at the same time developing respect, tolerance and equality.

The impact of this project on our institution will be the updating and innovation of methods, which will increase the quality of the teaching. It will also increase the motivation of students, which will improve their professionalism and allow them to be more competitive in the workplace. Thus, the JC1 will have a differentiating element from other institutions: it will incorporate new European-level methodologies into Vocational Training Education.

At the regional level, the results of the project will have an impact on companies in the professional fields of Chemistry and People in Need of Care, since promotion of our center and the participants through the project will result in developing interest in the hiring of our students and, in general, of collaborating with our educational center.

At the national level, the project promotes the development of the personal and social resources of our students in the search for employment. The diffusion of the impact of this project will reinforce the image of IES JC1 in the Murcia region, as well as on a national scope.

At the European level, the increase in contacts with companies will be important for future collaborations and exchange of experiences, as well as learning mobilities. The achievement of collaborations with educational centers as project partners will directly affect our teaching practice, giving it a European dimension. This fact can initiate a series of pedagogical collaborations with the teaching staff of the different educational systems that undoubtedly will open a new stage in the IES JC1, characterized by an international perspective of the professional profiles of its training cycles.
Project for higher education student and staff mobility between Programme Countries and Partner Countries
This is a project for higher education student and staff mobility between Programme Countries and Partner Countries. Please consult the website of the organisation to obtain additional details.

The Erasmus+ project, which is called "Spain trains in Northern Ireland", provides the opportunity to internationalize knowledge and labour promoting of those students and teachers motivated for change, in order to expand training and professional horizons. The program facilitates better cooperation between training institutions and employers, national and foreign, to ensure that students develop relevant curricula for the skills needed in the workplace.

Due to the positive results of the previous project (Improving Spain in Northern Ireland 2015-2017), we consider fundamental to repeat this opportunity again. And, these mobilities allow us to continue working for the development of potential and value of our students and staffs.

The project will be developed in South Eastern Regional College (SERC), Lisburn Campus, from Northern Ireland. Five of our students, from seventeen to twenty five years old mostly, have the opportunity to expand their academic and work experiences with colleagues from the Restoration area as a whole, and professionals in the field of Baking and Pastry, in the case of the practices in business. One of our teachers develops the same stay abroad too. According to this, the practices last 380 hours, distributed in two months and a half. The first two weeks will be spent in the training centre, and the remaining time in a company of the sector.. 

The project will assess the abilities of students in order to achieve the qualifications and level of training accredited by the title-degree. Also, take into account students adapt to a real business environment, initiative, willingness and innovation in the workplace. Related to teacher's mobility, the main objective to be achieved is to increase training center and enterprise techniques and processes of the host country (Northern Ireland). In this case it will be checked teaching methods, the raw materials, manufacturing processes and organizational capacity.

As already studied, there are various reasons why we recommend a workplace training abroad. First, is the opportunity to apply theoretical knowledge learned in social and business reality, placing the student to the real problems and making him or her decision true expertise through practice. Also, focusing on the development of practices in the European context involves the acquisition of new contacts that allow meet and work with many different groups of people.

The experimental practices in the European environment should generate a positive impact on improving the sociolinguistic competence of students, learning them to develop in a new and more complex environment. Moreover, students should be linked more directly with the labor and business world, knowing not only new techniques, processing and work processes, but also becoming more active role in labour relations through a good work team, and more and better decision making. And, undoubtedly, one of the benefits that can not be ignored regarding this training opportunity is the comprehensive development that students experience as a whole, in addition to improving and increasing levels of present and future employability.

The project offered 24 Level 3 BTEC students in Sport a two week traineeship with an employer from the sector in Malta, Luxol Sports Club.

Each group of 12 students were accompanied by two qualified lecturers for the first week and two in the second week. Staff were given the opportunity to engage with the employer with a view to developing international contacts and enhancing the curriculum. 

The project proposed to offer invaluable industry work placements addressing the students' needs for industry experience, with the opportunity to improve technical skills through practices in another European country, and the need to improve other skills required by employers today.

The students were placed with the partner with a focus on matching placements to the participants’ needs and areas of interest. The project utilised a partnership with an established and experienced organisation in Malta to provide quality work placements and relevant support for the learners. The Sports students were placed within massage, physiotherapy, nutrition and coaching at Luxol Sports Club.

The work placement opportunity gave practical experience within the fields required by the students’ course, exposing them to industry professionals, and the further personal development that this brings. There is added value from the European setting providing another level of skills and employability opportunities.

Project objectives: 
* Provide the students with much needed hands-on experience within the technical areas of their chosen industry, building on their skills and learning new methods and techniques
* Provide knowledge of industry practices within another European country
* Enhance the participants' understanding of the world of employment
* Develop the participants' personal and enterprise skills
* Introduce them to another culture and language
* Develop confidence and self-belief and life skills being placed in an unfamiliar foreign working environment and integrating into local society through the use of public transport etc.

As a result of the project the students have advanced their competences; have developed their personal, enterprise and employability skills; and gained an additional qualification all to the benefit of their studies and their future employment prospects.

In the longer term the project has allowed the College to develop its capacity to deliver a quality curriculum and European opportunities for staff and students. It has contributed to the College's main objectives as set out in the College Development Plan - "To improve the quality and relevance of education and training by providing a curriculum that will inspire, transform and enrich" and "To tackle the skills barriers to employment and employability".

The project offers the opportunity for two language teaching staff to take part in a 6 day language training course in Spain.

The project proposes to offer invaluable pedagogical training to the staff in order to up date them on methodologies and practices within language teaching.  It addresses the needs or the teaching staff to gain knowledge and skills in the topic which can be directly taken back and implemented in the classroom to have an affect on their students.

Participants will take part in an organised training activity with an experienced European provider.

Project objectives: 
* Provide the staff with development in their subject area, building on their skills and learning new methods and techniques
* Provide knowledge of practices within other European countries
* Develop the participants' personal and professional skills
* Introduce them to another culture and language
* Contribute to the internationalisation of the College and increase network of European contacts

It is expected that as a result of the training the participants will have met the project objectives above and longer term benefits are foreseen as improvements in retention and performance of language students, and collaborative projects in languages.
